newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-CANBERRA WATCH-Short fiasco couldn't have been worse.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-CANBERRA WATCH-Short fiasco couldn't have been worse.

text.p: The resignation of former assistant treasurer Jim Short has produced the worst possible outcome for the Liberal-National government from his unwise ownership of bank shares.
The government could not have suffered more damage from this modest-sized issue if it had tried. Worse, it gave up a chance to pick up some points from it last week.
The Labor Opposition first twigged on Wednesday to Short's ownership of bank shares, which was in conflict with his banking responsibilities within the treasury portfolio.
Opposition Leader Kim Beazley, probably mistakenly, dealt with the issue quite softly on Wednesday.
Labor sources say the opposition was not sure Short's declaration, in the register of senators interests, was was up to date.
As a result of this Howard could have sacked Short on Wednesday night and actually strengthened the government.
The action would have made him look strong in the most desirable of all subjects: propriety.
The Opposition, having barely raised the issue at that point, could not have claimed the scalp.
Also, Short was no star performer. Letting him go would have been an opportunity to promote a more promising backbencher into a trainee ministerial position.
Instead the prime minister decided to retain the minister, a long-time friend, and absorb the short-term political damage that would innevitably follow.
Howard made it worse for himself by telling parliament on Wednesday that he seriously considered dumping Short but had decided against it. It amounted to saying "I squibbed it."
Now, Short's resignation -- after his office discovered he had made a ministerial decision relevant to the shares -- means that the political pain was for nothing.
The government has lost the minister and worse, highlighted how wrong was the original decision not to dismiss him.
* Stephen Spencer, the Canberra bureau chief for Macquarie Network radio, is our guest columnist today.
